texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sometimes MySQL's process list will fill with unauthenticated login entries that look like this:
texts.text: Sometimes MySQL's process list will fill with unauthenticated login entries that look like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: |  971 | unauthenticated user | xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:35406 | NULL        | Connect | NULL | login | NULL             |
texts.text: |  971 | unauthenticated user | xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:35406 | NULL        | Connect | NULL | login | NULL             |

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Generally, this means one of two things are happening. First, this could be a brute force attack against your server from an external attacker. Be sure to firewall off access to port 3306 from the outside world or run MySQL with
texts.text: Generally, this means one of two things are happening. First, this could be a brute force attack against your server from an external attacker. Be sure to firewall off access to port 3306 from the outside world or run MySQL with

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: in the /etc/my.cnf file, and that should curtail those login attempts quickly.
texts.text: in the /etc/my.cnf file, and that should curtail those login attempts quickly.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, MySQL could be attempting to resolve the reverse DNS for each connection, and this definitely isn't necessary if your grant statements refer to remote machines' IP addresses rather than hostnames (as they should). In this case, add
texts.text: However, MySQL could be attempting to resolve the reverse DNS for each connection, and this definitely isn't necessary if your grant statements refer to remote machines' IP addresses rather than hostnames (as they should). In this case, add

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to your /etc/my.cnf and restart MySQL. These connection attempts should authenticate much faster, and they shouldn't pile up in the queue any longer.
texts.text: to your /etc/my.cnf and restart MySQL. These connection attempts should authenticate much faster, and they shouldn't pile up in the queue any longer.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Note:  Connections via sockets aren't affected by DNS resolution since sockets don't involve any networking access at all. If your web applications use 'localhost' for their connection string, then MySQL won't bring DNS resolution into play whatsoever.
texts.text: Note:  Connections via sockets aren't affected by DNS resolution since sockets don't involve any networking access at all. If your web applications use 'localhost' for their connection string, then MySQL won't bring DNS resolution into play whatsoever.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Recommended reading:  6.5.9. How MySQL Uses DNS
texts.text: Recommended reading:  6.5.9. How MySQL Uses DNS
